Record.Value: Basic Smelting
Smelt advanced metals and alloys
Gas Displays

Welcome back Cadet. Let's get smelting!
The {THING:StructureFurnace} is used to smelt ores into ingots and alloys for creating new technologies.
Your first task is to set up a {THING:CircuitboardGasDisplay} to display pressure and temperature inside the {THING:StructureFurnace}.
Pick up the {THING:CircuitboardGasDisplay} from the red crate.
Insert the {THING:CircuitboardGasDisplay} into the empty {THING:StructureConsole} on the wall behind the {THING:StructureFurnace}.
Pick up the {THING:ItemGlassSheets} from the red crate.
Install the {THING:ItemGlassSheets} on the {THING:StructureConsole}.
Configure Gas Display

You can now turn on and configure the {THING:StructureConsole}.
The {THING:StructureConsole} on the left will display pressure, so the new console will need to display temperature. After turning on the console and inserting the {THING:ItemDataDisk}, toggle the mode to 'Temperature' by clicking on the 'Pressure' option.
Now select the {THING:StructureFurnace} as the input device for the console. Scroll down until you see {THING:StructureFurnace} and select it.
Turn on the {THING:StructureConsole}
Insert the {THING:ItemDataDisk} from the crate into the {THING:StructureConsole}
Select the {THING:StructureFurnace} as the input device on the {THING:StructureConsole}, and change the mode to 'Temperature'.
Remove the data disk from the {THING:StructureConsole}.
How To Make Steel

To find the recipe for steel, open the Stationpedia with the {KEY:Help} key. Hold the {KEY:MouseControl} key and navigate to the 'Items' section, then click on the 'Alloys' link. On the 'Alloys' page, click the 'Ingot (steel)' link.
As you can see, you need three parts {THING:ItemIronOre} to one part Carbon or {THING:ItemCoalOre} to make Steel. These must be combined at a minimum temperature of 600K and a minimum pressure of 100.0kPa.
Open the Stationpedia
Navigate to the 'Ingot (steel)' page
Igniting The Furnace

To create steel, the {THING:StructureFurnace} must achieve the minimum required pressure and temperature. This can be done by adding volatiles and oxite ice directly to the furnace, or by providing a fuel mix.
The first method uses two parts volatiles and one part oxite. Be careful not to overload the {THING:StructureFurnace}, as adding too many oxites or volatiles may over pressurize the furnace and cause a devastating explosion.
Pick up the {THING:ItemVolatiles} from the red crate
Insert the {THING:ItemVolatiles} into the top of the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Press the red 'activate' button twice on the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Pick up the {THING:ItemOxite} from the red crate
Insert the {THING:ItemOxite} into the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Press the red 'activate' button on the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Smelting Iron

Like the {THING:StructureArcFurnace}, you can smelt ores in the {THING:StructureFurnace}, but you can also combine them. These alter the composition of the metals, creating new alloys. If you get the mix wrong you'll generate a {THING:ItemReagentMix} instead.
Start by adding three parts {THING:ItemIronOre} into the {THING:StructureFurnace}.
Pick up {THING:ItemIronOre} from the red crate
Put the {THING:ItemIronOre} in the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Making An Alloy
You can now turn the molten iron into steel. To do this, add one part {THING:ItemCoalOre} to the mix.
Pick up the {THING:ItemCoalOre} from the red crate
Put the {THING:ItemCoalOre} into the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Forming the Ingot
Use the Open Mold lever to open the {THING:StructureFurnace} and get the newly made {THING:ItemSteelIngot}. This will provide you with half of the required steel to make a {THING:ItemKitBattery}.
Pull the Open Mold lever on the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Pick up the {THING:ItemSteelIngot}
Insert the {THING:ItemSteelIngot} into the {THING:StructureElectronicsPrinter}
Venting The Gases

The {THING:StructureFurnace} is currently filled with highly pressurized toxic gas. You can vent it directly into the atmosphere. Alternatively you can cool, filter and recycle the gases for future use.
Before you try powering the {THING:StructureFurnace} with a fuel mix, you'll need to vent it. The output pipe is connected to a {THING:StructureValve} that prevents gases from escaping, and a {THING:StructureVolumePump} for venting.
Open the output {THING:StructureValve}
Turn on the {THING:StructureVolumePump}
Wait for the internal pressure in the {THING:StructureFurnace} to drop to 2kPa on the left display console.
Now that the gases have been vented, close the {THING:StructureValve} and turn off the {THING:StructureVolumePump}.
Close the {THING:StructureValve}
Turn off the {THING:StructureVolumePump}
Adding Fuel Mix

Now that the {THING:StructureFurnace} is empty, we can refill it another way, by piping a pre-prepared fuel mix into the input pipe.
The ideal fuel mix for the {THING:StructureFurnace} is a blend of 75% volatiles and 25% oxygen.
Make sure to close the Open Mold lever before refilling!
Open the input valve on the right side of the {THING:StructureFurnace}
Wait for the internal pressure of the {THING:StructureFurnace} to reach 100kPa
Quickly shut off the input valve - too much fuel mix could cause an explosion
Press the 'activate' button on the {THING:StructureFurnace}
New Alloy

Let's make another batch of steel. Just like last time we need to add three parts Iron and one part Coal. You can find more {THING:ItemIronOre} and {THING:ItemCoalOre} in the orange crate, which is now open.
Place {THING:ItemIronOre} into the furnace
Place {THING:ItemCoalOre} into the furnace
Open {THING:StructureFurnace} the using the Open Mold lever and remove the steel
What a Steel

We now have enough steel to create the {THING:ItemKitBattery}. The {THING:ItemKitBattery} can store large amounts of energy for your station.
Use the {THING:StructureElectronicsPrinter} to print the battery kit.
Pick up the {THING:ItemSteelIngot}
Insert the {THING:ItemSteelIngot} into the {THING:StructureElectronicsPrinter}
Turn on the {THING:StructureElectronicsPrinter}, look up {THING:ItemKitBattery}, and print it.
